story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Actor passed on praise she has been receiving for the filmPeople have been congratulating the wrong woman for directing Booksmart, mistaking actor Olivia Munn for director Olivia Wilde.Munn, who has starred in Ocean’s 8 and X-Men: Apocalypse, revealed on Twitter that people keep telling her how much they love Wilde’s 2019 comedy.“Last night a lot of people told me how much they love my movie @booksmart &amp how we need more female directors like me,” she wrote.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“First, I too loved that movie. Second, yes to more female directors! And lastly, @oliviawilde&nbsppeople love your movie &amp your directing, so wanted to pass that on.”Wilde then retweeted Munn’s post with three&nbspcrying-laughing emojis.Created with Sketch.19 films to look out for in 2020 Show all 19Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.An intoxicating and romantic drama about lovers on the run, Queen &amp Slim marks the first feature film from Melina Matsoukas, the director responsible for music videos including Beyoncé’s “Formation”. Daniel Kaluuya and Jodie Turner-Smith are the unlikely couple thrust together on a go-nowhere blind date, only for tragedy to transform them into folk heroes roaming across the USA searching for shelter. It’s a spellbinding debut. (Adam White) Guaranteed to be one of the major players in next year’s Oscars, Bong Joon-ho’s Parasite works better the less you know about it. What you should know is that it is a devilishly inventive deconstruction of class, brimming with energy, dark humour and nervous tension. (Adam White) Rising from the ashes of the aborted Universal Monsters multiverse, which was due to star Johnny Depp and Tom Cruise, this rebooted Invisible Man uses the iconic branding to tell the smaller and far more intriguing story of a woman on the run from her invisible ex. Elisabeth Moss is the domestic violence survivor convinced that her supposedly dead boyfriend has merely mastered the art of invisibility. Leigh Whannell, who directed 2018’s wonderfully inventive sci-fi thriller Upgrade, is behind the camera. (Adam White) A Quiet Place would surely have been better off as a standalone film, but the financial success of writer-director John Krasinski’s B-movie-style horror tale put paid to that. This isn’t to say there’s no more story to tell. In fact, Krasinski made no secret of the fact he had a whole universe he could one day explore, and sure enough, joining returning stars Emily Blunt, Millicent Thomas and Noah Jupe (so brilliant in Honey Boy) are new additions in the form of Cillian Murphy and Djimon Honsou. (Jacob Stolworthy) 519 No Time to DieWhile Daniel Craig’s Bond tenure has been marked by severe whiplash in terms of quality, there remains something incredibly exciting about the arrival of a new 007 movie. No Time to Die, Craig’s final outing as the super-spy, also boasts an intoxicating array of talent on and off screen, from Cary Fukunaga on directorial duties, to a script co-written by Phoebe Waller-Bridge and cast newcomers including Ana de Armas, Rami Malek and Lashana Lynch. (Adam White) Little is known about the plot for Antebellum, the feature film debut of artists and music video directors Gerard Bush and Christopher Renz. But the thriller's trailer is a visual feast, with Janelle Monáe appearing to be caught between the present day and the horrors of a 19th century plantation. From producer Jordan Peele, director of Get Out and Us, it also features Jena Malone, Gabourey Sidibe and Kiersey Clemons. (Adam White)719 The Woman in the WindowAn adaptation of the pulpy bestseller (which itself was engulfed in mystery when a New Yorker feature claimed its author, AJ Finn, had extensively lied about his personal life and history), The Woman in the Window puts Amy Adams centre stage for the first time since 2018’s Sharp Objects. She’s an agoraphobic psychologist convinced she has witnessed a murder across the street from her apartment. Julianne Moore, Gary Oldman and Brian Tyree Henry co-star. (Adam White) Watchmen star Yahya Abdul-Mateen III continues his incredible ascent with the starring role in this remake. Produced by the ubiquitous Jordan Peele, the new Candyman revives the hook-handed killer originated in 1992’s genuinely terrifying Bernard Rose film, but with a black and female director and predominantly black cast – which ought to mean the frustratingly ambiguous racial themes of the original can finally be given their due. (Adam White) The sequel to 2017’s mega successful Wonder Woman is a rare thing: a DC film worthy of excitement. The first outing saw Patty Jenkins become the highest-grossing woman director in cinema history, and she’s looking to beat her own record with a follow-up centred on the Amazon princess’s battle against a villain named Cheetah (Kristen Wiig in her superhero film debut). That Jenkins describes it as “a grand tentpole like they use to make in the 1980s” is reason alone to mark its release on your 2020 calendar. (Jacob Stolworthy) Soul is a curious new Pixar film that appears to emulate the philosophical wonder of Inside Out with the lived-in cultural exploration of Coco. Jamie Foxx is a struggling musician who finally gets his big break, only to experience a freak accident that propels him into a mysterious netherworld in which souls are imbued with talents and passions, before being implanted in newborn babies. It looks gorgeous, is potentially insane, and is co-written by Tina Fey. (Adam White) Hours after the first reviews of both Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker and Cats took over social media, Warner Bros dropped the trailer for Tenet, Christopher Nolan’s top secret espionage thriller. It’s fair to say plenty of sunshine was stolen – and for good reason. Tenet marks Nolan’s return to the mind-melting thrills of Inception and, while the plot remains unknown, it seems to focus on a team of heroes who must rewind time to prevent the outbreak of war. Sign us up. (Jacob Stolworthy) Tom Cruise is taking a (short) break from carrying out impossible missions in 2020. Instead, he’ll return to the cockpit for a sequel to the daddy of all Eighties films, Top Gun. There’ll surely be an element of “teach new dogs old tricks” in the Joseph Kosinski-directed film as Pete “Maverick” Mitchell mentors a new generation of US Navy fighter pilots. We’re hopeful the result will – wait for it – take our breath away. (Jacob Stolworthy) 1319 Barb and Star Go to Vista Del MarIt’s not the Bridesmaids sequel everyone begged for nearly a decade ago, but Barb and Star is its spiritual follow-up at least. Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumulo, the women behind the 2011 smash, write and star in this new comedy, playing two best friends who venture out of their small Midwestern community for the very first time. They soon get mixed up in a villainous plot to kill an entire town, while Jamie Dornan and Damon Wayans Jr also star. (Adam White) 1419 The Many Saints of NewarkWhether you like it or not, a film prequel based on The Sopranos is being released in 2020. The presence of David Chase, the HBO show’s creator, goes a long way to abate any concerns fans might have, and it’ll at least be a fine chance to explore the mobsters’s family history. The film is expected to focus on Dickie Moltisanti, the father of Christopher, whose memory loomed large over the series. (Jacob Stolworthy) 1519 Last Night in SohoEdgar Wright is adding “psychological horror” to his filmmaking repertoire with Last Night in Soho, a neon-soaked thrill ride starring quite the ensemble (Anya Taylor-Joy, Matt Smith, Diana Rigg). The intriguing plot focuses on a young girl for whom “time falls apart” after she’s somehow transported to the 1960s. It sounds like a cult hit in waiting. (Jacob Stolworthy) The feel-good West End smash is transformed into a feel-good movie, with Richard E Grant, Sarah Lancashire and Sharon Horgan leading the story of a teenage boy who overcomes insecurity by embracing drag. Newcomer Max Harwood portrays the title character. (Adam White) Regardless of whether you’re a keen follower of the Marvel Cinematic Universe or not, The Eternals should pique your interest. Sure, it may be spearheading a brand new phase of Marvel franchises – there really is no end to the studios’ box office stronghold – but it features what has to be one of the most eclectic casts ever seen in a superhero film: Angelina Jolie, Kit Harington, Kumail Nanjiani, Brian Tyree Henry and Salma Hayek. RodriguezGetty Images for DisneyA remake of David Lynch’s Dune would ordinarily cause our eyeballs to rattle around our sockets, but not when Denis Villeneuve’s in the director’s chair. The pair contrasted one another on the red carpet, Taylor in a white suit and Reeves in black.In January, Joaquin Phoenix vowed to wear the same custom-made Stella McCartney suit to every awards show in an effort to reduce waste.Salma Hayek looked angelic in a white, one-shoulder Gucci dress, accessorising with a silver headpiece and matching bangles.Maya Rudolph struck gold in a sequinned orange Valentino gown, accessorising with gold, strappy heels and wearing her hair in a chic bob.The Killing Eve star looked breathtaking in a gold, sequinned Elie Saab design, topped with a ruffled hem and shoulder details.The Jojo Rabbit director knows how to work a red carpet, as shown during his many red carpet appearances. During this year's Oscars, he chose to go for a somewhat understated black tux, a departure from his usual colourful style.Penelope Cruz's Chanel ensemble featured several different eye-catching elements, including a white rose, a pearl belt, a pocketed skirt and a halter neck.The Pitch Perfect actor dazzled in a gold, sequinned floor-length Jason Wu design.The singer had a Cinderella moment on the red carpet, donning an extravagant, unique, silver Ralph Lauren ballgown, designed with a matching hood.Olivia Colman, who won the Best Actress Oscar last year for her performance in The Favourite, attended this year's Academy Awards in a navy, cut-out, velvet Stella McCartney dress, complete with a train.5180 James Corden and Julia CareyCorden attended the awards ceremony wearing a black tuxedo, while his wife, Julia Carey, donned a silver, embellished gown with a royal blue belt.5280 Noah Baumbach and Greta GerwigLittle Women director Gerwig wore a strapless, khaki Dior dress on the red carpet, while her partner, Marriage Story director Baumbach, was dressed in a black suit.5380 Oscar Isaac and Elvira LindThe Star Wars actor donned a black suit for the occasion, while his wife, director and producer Elvira Lind, brightened up the red carpet in a sunshine yellow, layered gown.The Star Wars favourite opted for a black strapless Schiaparelli gown, designed with blue floral detailing at the top.The Veep star contrasted with the red carpet in a navy custom Vera Wang gown, accessorising with a eye-catching diamond necklace.The actor struck a pose on the red carpet, wearing a svelte navy suit.The singer stunned on the red carpet in a white Chanel ensemble, complete with lace gloves.The Oscar nominee opted for a pale pink Armani number with black detailing at the top, accessorising with understated jewels.The Late Night star attended the Academy Awards wearing a bright marigold one-shoulder Dolce and Gabbana gown with pleating detail.The Ugly Betty actor looked regal in a scarlet, floor-length Alberta Ferretti gown, accessorising with a golden headband. The Thai singer looked every inch a princess on the red carpet, wearing a stunning, off-the-shoulder, ombre, chiffon Poem couture gown.6280 Anthony Ramos and Jasmine Cephas JonesThe actors, who both starred in the original Broadway production of Hamilton, made for a stylish pair on the red carpet, Ramos in a white and black ensemble and studded shoes, and Jones in a black, blouson-sleeved Yanina couture gown.The Booksmart star brought a touch of old-school glamour in a white and black floral Miu Miu gown, her hair styled in classic waves.Billy Porter arrived on the red carpet in a skirt and top combination by Giles Deacon, accessorising with custom Jimmy Choo shoes.6580 Tonya Lewis Lee and Spike Lee Tonya Lewis Lee attended the Oscars in a white gown alongside filmmaker Spike Lee, who opted for a purple suit with yellow detailing. The Booksmart actor oozed glamour in a red, embellished, strapless Louis Vuitton gown.6780 Vanessa Nadal and Lin-Manuel MirandaHamilton creator Lin-Manuel Miranda looked chic in a black tuxedo, while his wife, lawyer Vanessa Nadal, contrasted in a white, embellished gown.The Irish actor made a bold entrance on the red carpet, wearing a black Valentino fishtail gown designed with a sheer, pink top and bow.Sigourney Weaver attended the Oscars in a green long-sleeved Dior gown with a matching clutch. Chrissy Metz attended the Oscars in a pillared red Christian Siriano gown. Regina King chose a pale pink structured Versace gown for the Oscars. Julia Butters also chose a pink outfit, arriving on the red carpet in a long-sleeved Christian Siriano gown with matching pink purse. Idina Menzel went with a pink theme, arriving on the red carpet in a strapless fuchsia J. Mendel gown. 7480 Ryan Piers Williams and America FerreraAmerica Ferrera chose a red Alberta Ferretti gown for the red carpet and accessorised with a headband. Ryan Piers opted for a simple black tuxedo. Zazie Beetz chose a strapless black Thome Brown dress for the Oscars. 7680 Kerri Higuchi and John ChoKerri Higuchi chose a black and silver Monique Huillier gown for the red carpet, while John Cho opted for a burnt orange Zegna suit. Robin Roberts arrived on the red carpet wearing a one-shouldered sparkling green Badgley Mischka gown. George MacKay opted for a simple tuxedo for the 92nd annual Oscars. Aurora arrived at the Oscars wearing a pale green ensemble by costume designer Viktoria Aksnes with red accents.Kelly Ripa arrived on the red carpet in a black structured one-shouldered Christian Siriano gown. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Mysterious pattern could be an important clue to the origin of mysterious blastsA mysterious radio signal coming from deep in space appears to be repeating in a pattern, say scientists.The powerful blast is coming from somewhere unknown and extragalactic, and is perhaps the most unusual fast radio burst ever detected by scientists.Researchers have already spotted a number of the fast radio bursts originating from deep in space. They have even seen that limited numbers of them appear to repeat.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesBut the new breakthrough, spotted by scientists using a telescope in Canada and described in an early paper published online, is the first time that researchers have seen the blasts appearing in a regular, predictable pattern.Astronomers have no confirmed explanation for the FRBs, with the only certain fact about their origin that they must be coming from somewhere very extreme and unusual. Proposed explanations have included everything from alien civilisations sending us messages to a star falling into a black hole, but the fact that the messages are repeating have led some scientists to lead out such cataclysmic causes.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Nasa's groundbreaking decade of space exploration: In pictures Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Mystic Mountain, a pillar of gas and dust standing at three-light-years tall, bursting with jets of gas flom fledgling stars buried within, was captured by Nasa's Hubble Space Telelscope in February 2010The first ever selfie taken on an alien planet, captured by Nasa's Curiosity Rover in the early days of its mission to explore Mars in 2012Death of a star: This image from Nasa's Chandra X-ray telescope shows the supernova of Tycho, a star in our Milky Way galaxyArrokoth, the most distant object ever explored, pictured here on 1 January 2019 by a camera on Nasa's New Horizons spaceraft at a distance of 4.1 billion miles from EarthAn image of the Large Magellanic Cloud galaxy seen in infrared light by the Herschel Space Observatory in January 2012. It has since been suggested that they may instead be formed by flowing sand NasaJPLUniversity of ArizonaMorning Aurora: Nasa astronaut Scott Kelly captured this photograph of the green lights of the aurora from the International Space Station in October 2015The FRBs are in a 16-day cycle that sees them appear and then go dark, before doing the same all over again. Over the course of the cycle, the bursts will appear intensely for a four day flurry that sees a signal come every hour or more, and then it will go quiet for 12 days.That pattern is an important clue to the nature of this object, the researchers write in the new paper.Are aliens sending us messages from light years away?It appears to be coming from the edge of a massive spiral galaxy, about 500 million light years away, the researchers say. But there are few other clues about where it could be coming from or the processes that may have given rise to it.The fact that it is repeating over a predictable period could suggest that it is coming from a binary system, since other objects in space that demonstrate similar characteristics tend to be binary systems, too. The object could be being swung around by a star or black hole, and the periodic blasts could be an indication that the object is facing us during those times, the researchers say.It could also be possible that winds or tidal disruptions from the black hole block the signal during the periods it is silent, they note.The repeating signals were spotted by the&nbspCanadian Hydrogen Intensity Mapping Experiment, which spends time looking for more FRBs in an attempt to find their origin. It should spend more time looking at the source of the current bursts – known as&nbspFRB 180916.J0158+65 – in an attempt to learn more about it, the researchers conclude in their paper, which is for now published on the website ArXiv before being peer reviewed and published in a journal.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. to halt charter flightThe government has said it will push ahead with a charter flight removing around 50 people to Jamaica despite widespread demands for the mass deportation to be called off.Chief Secretary to the Treasury Rishi Sunak insisted that those set to be forcibly removed on Tuesday – on the second charter flight to the country since the&nbspWindrush&nbspscandal – had committed “very serious offences” such as rape and murder, and their deportations were “reasonable”.However, it has emerged that in a number of cases those facing deportation have committed less serious crimes such as drug supply, GBH or joint-enterprise crimes, often only once and many years ago – raising questions around whether their removal is proportionate.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe Home Office would not release any breakdown on the nature of offences committed by those scheduled to be on the flight.Many of the deportees have also been in the UK for decades and have children here – with campaigners estimating that at least 41 British children&nbspare at risk of losing their fathers as a result of the charter flight.In one case, The Independent revealed that Reshawn Davis, 30, who has been in the UK since the age of 11 and has a six-month-old British daughter, is set to be removed on the basis that he was convicted for robbery 10 years ago under the now-unlawful “joint enterprise” rule – for which he spent two months in prison.Man who has been in UK since age 11 set to be deportedMore than 170 cross-party MPs have written a letter calling on the prime minister to halt the flight&nbspuntil the publication of the&nbspWindrush lessons learned review – of which a draft&nbspleaked to the media last week&nbspsaid ministers should consider ending the practice of deporting people who arrived in the UK as children.The letter also demands that people set to be removed are provided with effective access to justice, after it emerged that a mobile phone outage at Heathrow removal centres meant detainees were struggling to pursue challenges against their removal directions.Speaking to Sky News on Monday, Mr Sunak defended the flight, insisting it was “right” and the British public would expect foreign national offenders to be deported.“Many of these people have committed crimes such as manslaughter, rape, other very serious offences. It's reasonable, it's proportionate, and something the British people would expect us to do for foreign criminals who have committed very serious crimes who should be sent back to their countries where they have a right to reside elsewhere, he said.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailWhen asked about the case of Tajay Thompson, who is facing deportation after serving half of a 15-month sentence in 2015 for possessing class A drugs with intent to supply at 17, Mr Sunak said he was not familiar with the case but insisted “all due process will have been followed”.MPs Nadia Whittome and Dawn Butler raise point of status of people on next week’s deportation flight to JamaicaLabour MP Nadia Whittome, who organised the letter protesting against the charter flight, said:&nbsp“The fact is that many of the iniduals in question have lived in the UK since they were children and at least 41 British children are now at risk of losing their fathers through this charter flight.“The government risks repeating the mistakes of the&nbspWindrush&nbspscandal unless it cancels this flight and others like it until the&nbspWindrush&nbspLessons Learned Review has been published and its recommendations implemented.”Labour MP David Lammy&nbspsaid it was scandalous that the government was pushing ahead with the charter flight despite knowing&nbspthe Windrush Lessons Learned Review suggests&nbspmany of these men should not be deported.He added: We know that many of those scheduled to be deported came to the UK as children as young as two, five, seven&nbspand 11. &nbsp&nbspAlthough the Met Office’s amber warning for wind ended on Sunday evening, a yellow wind warning is still in place for many parts of the UK on Monday.Travel disruption to continue as Storm story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.West Midlands and north west of England see the biggest dropThe number of lollipop men and women employed in Britain has been cut by more than 2,000 in the past decade, according to a new study.The GMB union blamed years of austerity&nbspfor the reduction and warned that&nbspit was affecting the safety of children walking to and from school.The union made a Freedom of Information request to local authorities across Britain, asking how many school-crossing patrol officers they employed in the last financial year compared with&nbsp2009-10.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIn 2009-10, there were 7,128 employed by councils across England, Scotland and Wales. contact with wildlife”. The majority of the patients had contracted the virus from being in contact with people from Wuhan, where the centre of the outbreak is.More than 80 percent of patients developed lymphopenia, which is a state where a specific white blood cell that is part of the body’s first-line defence against diseases is reduced.Lymphopenia is commonly caused by infections and the flu, and usually recovers on its own after the patient recovers.The 55 patients observed in the study were admitted into the intensive care unit, some with severe pneumonia as a result of the virus. title: coronavirus gp practice brighton
story: The County Oak Medical Centre is on lockdown due to an urgent operational health and safety reason as the grim total of Brits with the disease today rose to eight.It is understood one of the new confirmed cases is reportedly a doctor from Brighton who was part of a group at the ski resort struck down by the bug, according to the .The GP was at work for one day but did not treat any patients and instead did admin work, the Argus reports.People in hazmat suits could be seen working inside the surgery today after it was closed wiping down doors.A sign pinned on the front has urged patients to ring the NHS  phone servicethey have concerns.It comes after health chiefs announced four patients were being treated for the virus in Brighton - bringing the total number of Brits infected to eight.The new cases are all known contacts of a super-spreader businessman who was diagnosed in the town last week.He is now said to be at the centre of a web of cases across the UK, Spain and France.The man had contracted the virus at a conference in Singapore before travelling to a ski chalet in France.Five other Brits at the chalet were then taken ill with the deadly virus, which has claimed more than  lives and infected , people globally.Among these is Bob Saynor, who owns the ski chalet in Contamines-Montjoie, and his nine-year-old son.Last night French health minister Agnes Buzyn revealed his we Catriona, , was under observation in a UK hospital.Coronavirus fears are also now heightened in Hove - including at Portslade Community Academy pupil being treated in self isolation after coming into contact with the super-spreader.Five staff members at The Grenadier Pub in Hove are also in self-isolation at home after the man visited the boozer between pm and pm last Saturday.Volunteers at a community centre are also in self-isolation after the man went to a yoga class last week.One user told the Argus: People are very concerned about the lack of clear information from the NHS about this mans movements.And a Brit dad was also quarantined in a Majorca hospital after testing positive and Spanish authorities appeared to confirm the case was again linked to the French ski chalet.Professor Chris Whitty, the chief medical officer for England, said: “Experts at Public Health England continue to work hard tracing patient contacts from the UK cases.They successfully identied these iniduals and ensured the appropriate support was provided.“The patients have been transferred to specialist NHS centres at Guy’s and St Thomas’ and The Royal Free hospitals, and we are now using robust infection control measures to prevent further spread of the virus.The NHS is extremely well prepared to manage these cases and treat them, and we are working quickly to identy any further contacts these patients have had.A frantic search is now underway to find the hundreds of people the original spreader may have had contact with.The mystery man was unaware he contracted the virus during a conference at the Grand Hyatt hotel in Singapore organised by British gas firm Servomex.He flew back to the Gatwick from Geneva on an easyJet flight with  passengers and six crew on January .In a statement easyJet said:easyJet has been notied by the public health authority that a customer who had recently travelled on one of its flights has since been diagnosed with the Coronavirus.Public Health England is contacting all customers on the flight which was flight EZS from Geneva to London Gatwick on  January, to provide guidance in line with procedures.As the customer was not experiencing any symptoms, the risk to others on board the flight is very low.We remain in contact with the public health authorities and are following their guidance.The health and well-being of our passengers and crew is the airlines highest priority.All of the crew who operated have been advised to monitor themselves for a -day period since the flight in line with Public Health England advice. Note this happened  days ago and none are displaying any symptoms.It comes as the Government declared coronavirus a serious and imminent threat to public health as it introduced new powers to deal with the spread of the virus.Under new powers announced today, the health ministry said people with the illness can now be forcibly quarantined and will not be free to leave, and can be forcibly sent into isolationthey pose a threat to public health.The measures are understood to have been introduced after a Brit attempted to flee a Milton Keynes quarantine centre.Around  Brits were flown to Arrowe Park in the city from coronavirus ground zero Wuhan and have agreed to remain there for the -day quarantine period.Meanwhile,  more people on the quarantined Diamond Princess cruise ship in the port of Yokohama have tested positive for the disease.There are now  confirmed cases on the ship with more than , people, including  Brits, still in a -day quarantine on board.And where in the UK, a University of York student and their relative are still being treated at the Royal Victoria Infirmary infectious diseases centre in Newcastle for the bug.There have been more than , cases of the virus globally, mostly in China, while the death toll in China now stands at .More to follow...For the latest news on this story keep checking back at Sun Online.Thesun is your go to destination for the best celebrity news, football news, real-le stories, jaw-dropping pictures and must-see video.Download our fantastic, new and improved free App for the best ever Sun Online experience. title: secret world vip fixers stars celebrities dubai mykonos
story: When the rich and famous want to let their hair down in the likes of Dubai, Mykonos or London, they often turn to local fixers who can make their every wish come true.But in a world where money is no object and appearances are everything, it also requires some seriously creative thinking to stay on top of the game.Speaking exclusively to the Sun Online, two Brit expats who gave up dead-end -to- jobs in the UK to chase sex, drugs and sunshine lt the lid on what the stars really get up to on holiday.It almost seems too good to be true. Earning huge sums of money while hanging out with your sporting heroes, favourite actresses and musicians.But Chris and Jordan* are just two of a growing number of Brits who are making new lives for themselves abroad by acting as a well-connected middle man.Chris, , moved to the United Arab Emirates four years ago, tempted by the tax-free salaries and luxury living.He started off as an estate agent, but working on a commission-only basis meant he struggled to fund his expensive tastes.One night, a friend introduced him to a Premier League footballer and it sparked an unlikely new career.Today, Chris is the go-to guy for top sports stars, reality television stars and Instagram influencers in Dubai. He tells us he can now make up to £, a month from famous faces who want him to deliver the perfect holiday.And he says it is something most people could make a good living out of with a bit of nous, charm and luck.He tells us: “I started out a few years ago with absolutely no experience in this kind of thing and with no celebrity contacts to help me. But I slowly grew my contacts book through word of mouth and now I am even turning people away who I don’t think are worth the hassle.“The key is taking the rough with the smooth. There are going to be dficult times, but you just have to deal with them and remember you are nothing without your reputation.”But Chris has had more than his fair share of trouble in paradise.He says: “On the face of it, I am living the best le in the world. My friends back home see me on Instagram partying with famous faces, enjoying boozy parties, the best food and the hottest nightclubs.“What they don’t see is that I’ve had to live in a tiny maid’s room for a year because a reality star didn’t pay me the £, bill he racked up on champagne and drugs.“I’ve tried desperately to get it back, but he doesn’t answer his phone and he blocked me on social media, so I don’t think I’ll be seeing that money again.“I had another bad experience with a soap actress who flew over for the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix. I got her into an ultra-exclusive yacht party with some rich UAE businessmen, but she downed so much champagne she vomited on the dance floor. Needless to say, I wasn’t invited to the party the following year.”For Chris, image is everything.He tells how he uses a range of tactics to give the impression he is the perfect one-stop VIP concierge, from hiring designer suits for the day to blagging free hotel stays and slap-up meals in exchange for Instagram posts from stars.On one occasion, he was so desperate to impress an England international footballer, he rented a stunning apartment in the world’s tallest building, the Burj Khala, that cost £, for one night – just so he could pretend it was his own home.He says: “I deal with really expensive experiences, so sometimes I have to stump up my own cash as I don’t want people to think I’m a fraud. Helicopter rides, boozy brunches, supercar rentals - they all cost money. In thrill-a-minute Dubai, money can buy you anythingyou know the right people.But his work has sometimes left him having panic attacks and fearing jail when things go wrong.He says: “The clients I deal with are usually pretty high net worth people, but it’s definitely true that money can’t buy class.“One of my clients was a really arrogant singer who thought he was the king of Dubai, even though hardly anyone outside of the UK would know who he is.“He got drunk and had a minor brawl with a guy in a bar, but he was so paranoid about the Dubai police scare stories he had heard that he went straight to the airport and flew home.”The UAE is an Islamic country and has uber-strict laws on alcohol, drugs and public indecency. Chris says that some tourists arrive in Dubai believing boozing is illegal and women must dress conservatively, but are surprised when they see how liberal the desert city really is.High-class prostitutes are a familiar sight in many nightclubs, and while drugs such as cocaine and MDMA are not quite as accessible as in the UK, they can still be bought from well-connected dealers.“Dubai is nowhere near as strict as people often think it is,” says Chris. “You see scare stories in the news but there is always more to them than meets the eye.“It’s the perfect place for British celebrities to come and let their hair down as the huge cultural ersity means they aren’t as likely to be recognised as they would be at home.“Often the celeb will be posting a beach photo on Instagram to give the impression of a chilled break, while in real le they’re up to their eyes in drugs, sex and once-in-a-letime thrills.”Dubai’s reputation as a party paradise has been hard earned over many years, but celebrities are always keen to discover new and exciting destinations.The picture perfect Greek island of Mykonos has now firmly established itself as a rival to the UAE when it comes to A-list visitors.Celebrities are lured by the dazzling blue waters, rugged scenery and, of course, the luxury lestyle on offer.Jordan, , is a DJ living in oil rich Abu Dhabi, but has a network of contacts in Mykonos that allows him to spread his net a little further.Now he has a phone book full of famous faces who drop him a line when they want the inside track on the holiday hotspot.He says: “Mykonos is definitely rivalling Ibiza and Dubai in the holiday stakes, but it’s not all about partying.“This year, the likes of Kendall Jenner, Cristiano Ronaldo and Leigh-Ann Pinnock have all been here to enjoy some downtime.“I’ve probably made more than £, working with a number of UK celebrities over the summer, helping them with everything from organising mega parties to doing their laundry.“It’s a millionaires’ playground, for sure, and while it generally attracts a higher-class crowd than most places, you still get plenty of people who take things too far.”He recalls: “I helped an international footballer out when he arrived here in summer and hired an expensive boat for him and his mates. But they got drunk and absolutely trashed it. There were a few smashed windows, and a big dent in one of the safety rails on the side of the boat, and it cost thousands of pounds to repair it.“I also caught a reality star having sex on the beach after a particularly boozy night out. I can’t help but feel bad for his long-term girlfriend, who he’s always posting about his love for on Instagram.”Many of us wish we could make a living out of travelling the world like a growing number of travel influencers.And while for some it is little more than a pipe dream, Jordan has his sights firmly set on global domination. His job in Abu Dhabi allows him the flexibility to travel regularly and he hopes one day to become a full-time travel influencer.He says: “I always used to see people on Instagram who had given up their jobs to travel the world and I always wondered how they could afford it. But it turns out anyone with a decent number of followers on social media can blag free hotel stays in exchange for posts.“I’ve collaborated with a few places around the world and got free stays, and I’m hoping in a few years to quit working and do that full-time.“I love being able to do what I do now and it is a lot of fun, but I know I won’t be able to do it forever.“My dream is to be able tohome to the UK and buy a house in the countryside mortgage-free, then retire by the age of .”* The names in this story have been changed to protect their identity.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: praise british coast people
story: But rarely in all the debate about what our future now holds do you hear about the wonders of our coastline — which, when you think we have more than , miles of it, doesn’t feel right.Presenting Our Coast with Mehreen Baig, I’ve seen just how beautul it is, and how many brilliant people live their lives there.They are a special breed of unsung heroes.It can be tough for sure, in places the rest of us used to holiday — places we profess to love, often without actually doing that much to nurture.There are challenges in many coastal communities, and they definitely need the money politicians of all stripes have promised them.But I’ve also been struck by how hard they’re working to turn things around themselves. There is often hope where we may first see ­dficulty. You just have to look a bit harder sometimes.In Portpatrick, at Scotland’s bottom left corner, the harbour had fallen into miserable disrepair. A plan was hatched to stop the rot.A local hero organised a share issue for locals to raise the money to buy the harbour and restore the buildings around it. The village now has its pecker up again and the future looks bright.It’s a similar story on Anglesey. At Halen Mon a thriving family business draws water out of the Menai Strait, harvests the salt and sells it all over the world.Near there I met a woman called Sian Sykes who cared about those waters so much she paddle-boarded  miles around Anglesey picking out the plastic.Asthat wasn’t enough, she then paddled the whole coast of Wales doing exactly the same.But my favourite character round there is no longer with us. On the very western tip of Holy Island off Anglesey’s west coast, there is the South Stack lighthouse. It’s been saving sailors from watery deaths since .A hundred years ago, John Jones was its keeper and it was his great granddaughter Denise Shaw who took me up to the top of it.Denise showed me a photograph of her great-grandad sporting a magnicent moustache the seagulls must have coveted for their nests.He was no loner, though. Denise remembers her mum saying old great-gramps was a bit of a ladies’ man.And what a chat-up line he had at his disposal: “Do you want to come back to my place to see how bright my light is ”All four of the areas we’ve looked at for this series of Our Coast are around the Irish Sea. I had a brilliant time at Belfast docks where I joined the harbour pilots, whose work astounded me.It’s their job to bring the giant ships safely into port.I sort of assumed they did this by chugging out to meet them, lighting up a sign saying, “follow me” and gently leading them to their berths.Far from it. Round the clock, all year round, whatever the weather, they race out several miles to pull up alongside these huge vessels.Incredibly, a rope ladder is dropped over the side for the pilots to clamber aboard, make their way to the bridge, take over the controls and steer these monsters into tight spaces on the docks.The ship I boarded with them, somewhat terried, was carrying grain from Romania.As my man took the helm I asked the Polish skipper which country had the best harbour pilots. “You do,” he said, with feeling.Back across the Irish Sea, in Formby, north of Liverpool, I met Mike McComb in the £million place he’s built himself a stone’s throw from the sea.He has more bedrooms, bathrooms and children than I could count .His fortune could have bought him a lavish home anywhere in the world. But it was up here, along the endless beach, that back in the day he and his mates would come on their bikes from their tiny homes in Bootle.So, he tells me as we stand on the beach, lashed by rain and wind, you can keep St Tropez or Malibu. This coast, his coast, is where he’ll stay.The sea seems to be a magnet for the most memorable people, from Grace the crane engineer in Belfast Docks who played rugby for Ireland in three rugby world cups, to Sandy the tattooed pagan near Stranraer who says the sea’s our mother, and the Bulgarian dissident I chanced upon sitting in a hot tub ­surveying Liverpool from the deck of the Queen Mary .My grandad used to tell me that when you put your toe in the sea you’re connected with the whole world.With that in mind, I’ve enjoyed many a paddle this summer reflecting on the power and history of what our island nation is all about.And I urge you to do it, too. After all, it’s pretty easy. Britain’s most landlocked place — Coton in the Elms in Derbyshire — is just  miles from the coast. So none of us is more than a couple of hours away from the sea.There’s never been a more relevant time to get out to the edges and see the soul of this country.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus uk china wuhan live updates
story: Four more people have tested positive for coronavirus in the UK today.A Brighton GP surgery is in lock down and confirms a staff member is infected.The number of deaths has rocketed to  with coronavirus which he caught after refusing to wear a surgical mask.Qiu Jun, from the viral outbreaks epicentre Wuhan in Central Chinas Hubei Province, survived just four days in hospital before dying of fatal pneumonia-like symptoms on th February, his family has confirmed.The pensioner, who only began exercising when he retired in  at the age of , was well known as a bodybuilding champion, claiming numerous prizes in the senior category.He was often seen working out in Zhongshan Park, where he would often spend three hours doing press-ups or pull-ups, before breaking for lunch and continuing in the afternoon.But despite repeated reminders, Mr Qiu did not stop exercising and continued to go to his gym until the entire city of Wuhan was put on lockdown on rd January.https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   AsiaWire-MuscleVirus-.jpgThe coronavirus super spreader may have been to a yoga class in Hove.Staff at the community centre which hosts the class have title: kirk douglas was the one and only spartacus and he had balls of steel
story: When Kirk came into the world, the Battle of the Somme was still raging and Sir Ernest Shackleton — my own hero — was fighting to save his men on a doomed Antarctic expedition.At , Kirk’s death was not unexpected. But it saddened us all because it felt like this incredible human being would go on for ever.He headed the Douglas dynasty with a zest for le that put the rest of us to shame and was one of our final links to Hollywood’s golden age.Long before actors ostentatiously wore their hearts on their sleeves and made self-aggrandising speeches about the latest trendy cause, Kirk determinedly set out to do the right thing, regardless of any impact on his career.In the Fties, at the height of the Cold War, he stood up to a paranoid US government that considered anyone to the left of Genghis Khan a Soviet sympathiser.The McCarthy witchhunts ruined careers and wrecked lives, but Kirk dug in his heels and hired blacklisted writer Dalton Trumbo to work on Spartacus, which would become Kirk’s most famous movie.That took balls of steel.Kirk gave millions to charity and was a US Goodwill Ambassador, receiving the Presidential Medal of Freedom from Jimmy Carter in .He experienced heartache with the death of his son Eric from an overdose and the jailing of grandson Cameron for drug offences.But even a near-fatal helicopter crash and a stroke couldn’t defeat Kirk.His son Michael — a superstar in his own right, of course — told me last year his dad worked out almost every day with a personal trainer and remained as sharp as a tack, keeping the whole extended family on their toes.I was lucky enough to interview Kirk back in my days with TV-am.The Beeb would fly them over from LA and put them up in a posh hotel.All we could offer was a hearty breakfast, plus the chance to talk about themselves and their new project for as long as they liked.There were no pesky managers and PRs to go through.Bette Davis, Burt Lancaster, Lauren Bacall and Sammy Davis Jnr all popped into our studio at the crack of sparrows, staying for the duration of the show.Kirk was here in , promoting Dance With The Devil, a racy novel that bore a passing resemblance to his extraordinary le story.After his Jewish parents escaped persecution in Russia, Kirk was born and raised in a poor area of New York.It is a real rags-to-riches tale. His dad actually worked as a rag-and-bone man.Kirk never forgot where he came from, which is perhaps why he became a champion for justice and a fairer society.He was a delight that morning and even laughed when the crew declared, “I’m Spartacus”, one after another in his honour — though he must have seen it done hundreds of times before.He was a also a much-loved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather.The Douglas clan will be in mourning but they can celebrate a le well lived.This weekend, I am on a Kirk Douglas marathon, starting with Paths Of Glory, before The Bad And The Beautul, Ace In The Hole, The Vikings, Lust For Le and, of course, Spartacus.Tomorrow’s Oscars will rightly honour him. We won’t see his like again.I WAS honoured to host The Millies this week.It is a wonderful event run by The Sun to salute our Armed Forces and give us all a chance to say a huge thank you.As always, there were astonishing stories of bravery, courage and self-sacrice.And as always, our lovely winners told me they were nothing special, just doing their job.I honestly don’t think they realise just how remarkable they are, or how much we owe them.One of my highlights was seeing -year-old Private Fin Doherty collect his award for inspiring others.Fin was just six when his paratrooper big brother JJ was killed in action in Afghanistan.Fin was determined to follow in JJ’s footsteps to honour his brother’s memory, and join the Parachute Regiment.He has been an outstanding addition and, in an emotional ceremony, was presented with JJ’s beret in December.Their mum Joyce admits she struggled with Fin’s decision to sign up, following the death of her eldest son.But she knew it was all Fin wanted – and she is so very proud of him.We honestly don’t deserve such an inspirational young man. But thank the Lord we have him on our side.NOTHING has changed. Phillip Schofield is exactly the same person he was before he felt the time was right to tell the world he’s gay.He’s still a loving father and husband and will still host his TV shows with consummate professionalism and skill.As Phillip said himself, you never know what people are struggling with every day and, for him, it was time to be honest with himself and everyone .I’m really glad that he has made the decision and very proud of him, although obviously it can’t have been easy.There’s been lots of tears, sleepless nights and a great deal of soul-searching. I hope he now finds peace of mind.He is a very lucky man to have a family and friends who love him very much and just want him to be happy.He also has a loyal fan base who love watching him on This Morning and that won’t change. Why would it Of course, he can expect a small number of bigots and homophobes to spew out hateful bile, but they are to be pitied and ignored.Those carping about why he took so long also need to shut up.People should be allowed to come out when it feels the right time for them.Phillip began his career at a time when being openly gay in a TV presenting role was just not an option.Thank goodness things have changed and he can be open now – and know that the overwhelmingly vast majority of us wish him and his family nothing but the very best.I was really touched by what he said about interviewing brave people on This Morning, and realising that he had to be just like them and tell his truth.Love comes in many dferent forms.Phillip and his we Stephanie adore each other and that won’t change. Again, why on earth would it At the end of his statement Phillip urged us all to be kind, especially to his family, and I hope we all take those words on board.Let’s wish them all the best and let them get on with their lives.WHAT a furore over a bare shoulder. Actress-turned-MP Tracy Brabin didn’t deserve the vitriol about her outfit but it WAS distracting.It’s unfortunate because Tracy was making important points about journalists being shut out of No  briefings – a move that makes my blood run cold and threatens Press freedom. Sadly, no one was really listening.Tracy told me she had been at a music event and didn’t expect to be back in the House. She is bemused by all the fuss.How those in public le dress should not detract from their message, be it a female MP in a low-cut top or mini-skirt, or a man wearing a gaudy tie or tight trousers.Our MPs are not known for their style and rarely make headlines for their fashion sense.I am very happy for them to keep it that way.WELL, that was a rather ill-advised memo to send, reminding local councils to fly the Union Flag on February  as a “celebration” of Prince Andrew’s birthday.I had no idea this was a “thing” and that Andrew was on a list of VIPs whose birthdays are marked with a flag waving on the roof of our town halls, instead of just cake and prosecco like the rest of us.Unsurprisingly, this ludicrous edict has caused much disgruntlement.As we know, Andrew has been booted out of The Firm by his own mum after that disastrous TV interview delving into his friendship with the American paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.Then there is the ongoing scandal over whether or not Andrew will be interviewed by the FBI as part of its investigations into child trafficking allegations against Epstein.It is all very sordid and murky. Surely even his nearest and dearest would agree this is not the time for official celebrations.He is no longer a working royal and has no place on that list.Time to lower the flags for good. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: andrew tip caroline dont speak out
story: And then straight away I started wondering about the more important things in le such as: What shall I have for breakfast I think that she ended up in court and I have it in my mind that she pleaded not guilty.I’m also fairly sure that she’s not allowed to speak with her boyfriend until the case comes to court. But I can’t be sure, as I have other things to think about like: I need some new trousers.Then out of the blue she announced on social media that she was going to speak out because “mine and my families le is no longer up for entertainment or gossip”.“Wow,” I thought. “That’s amazing. She doesn’t know how to use apostrophes.”It turns out, however, that while she can’t write properly, she can at least think straight because she never did speak out. Which means she stopped the story from rearing up again.If only Prince Andrew was as bright. We were all dimly aware that he knew a man in America who’d had lots of sex with young girls.And that one day, this man had been found dead in a police cell. Then we went back to wonderingwe needed more washing-up liquid.Prince Andrew, however, decided that instead of letting the story die down by not saying anything, he’d go on television to set the record straight.It was a disaster. He was suddenly front-page news all over the world and he looked guilty as hell.Of what, we weren’t sure. But whatever it was, we all worked out that as he has a Bentley, he could definitely have got from a Pizza Express restaurant in Woking to the centre of London in less than six hours.A few weeks later, as the story was withering once more, Hank J Dieselburger, an American prosecutor involved in the dead sex-man’s case, announced that the FBI had received “zero co-operation” from Prince Andrew.You’d think Andrew would have learned from his earlier mistake. You’d think he’d do a Flack and say nothing.But no. The very next day, “friends” of the Prince — which is another way of saying “the Prince” — went on the attack, telling reporters he was angry and bewildered. “They haven’t even approached me — I mean him.”The problem is that ego-fed celebrities read every single thing that is written about them. And they believe everyone  is reading everything, as well.We aren’t. We don’t really care. So when you attempt to clear your name, it’s like trying to put out a fire with petrol.It’s better for Andrew, and the whole Royal Family,he takes a leaf from singer Ronan Keating’s book — “You say it best, when you say nothing atThen, perhaps, he could take a leaf from his nephew’s book. And bugger off to Canada.I’M not defending drugs here, but when you see someone giggling their way through a packet of frozen peas and some leftover sherry trle at five in the morning, it’s easy to see why someone might think: “Yes, that cannabis malarkey looks like fun. I shall give it a go.”It’s the same story with cocaine.You see a dullard finding himself absolutely fascinating at a party and you think: “I’ll have a crack at that.”But this new drug, flakka, is dferent.One man who took it ate a homeless man’s face. Another gouged her own mother’s eyes out. And a third cut off his own penis.Which raises an interesting point. Why would anyone look at someone cutting off his old fella and think, “Ooh, I’ll have what he’s having ”A BUNCH of people who think the Lake District should only be used by ramblers decided to stage a protest over plans to put ten small tourist yachts on Grasmere lake.However, before the protest could take place, the idea was abandoned. And guess what  Yup. The protest went ahead anyway.They were actually protesting about something that wasn’t going to happen. Which proves what I’ve suspected for quite some time. Ramblers aren’t entirely right in the head.Next week, they will be protesting about the sonic booms made by Concorde and the burning of witches.LAST Sunday, driving was banned in the Italian city of Milan.Who thought that was a good idea  Getting an Italian to leave his car at home is impossible. It’s a part of his being, like his liver and his lungs.Needless to say, the scheme was not very successful.So not very successful in fact that, in the first three hours, the police had issued  fines. And the authorities now admit the ban was “largely ignored”.THERE’S much talk at the moment about how internet shopping is killing the High Street. But I’m not one of the murderers.When the time comes for my annual clothes shopping trip, I simply head to the Levi’s store on Regent Street in London, point at the label on the back of the jeans I’m wearing and ask for three more pairs just the same.I love Levi’s. I’ve worn nothing  since I was  and I’ve always loved their shop, the staff have always been brilliant. They always have what I need in stock and they never ask for my phone number or email address. I’m in and out in two minutes flat.This year, though, there was a disaster. There were two disinterested youths in there who looked at the label on the back of my jeans and said, “We don’t make those any more.”WHAT  ! !On the verge of fainting with shock, I dragged them back from their interesting conversation about Stormzy and was told in an exasperated fashion that I could still buy them online.This begs a question. What’s the point of having an expensive-to-run shopyou then fill it with people who tell you to go home and buy what you need on the net PETA, an organisation for animal enthusiasts who like to wear clothes made from crude oil, have announced that people often see their pet dog as nothing more than a cheap burglar alarm.Cheap You can buy a home alarm kit these days for less than £, whereas a proper dog is going to be way more than that.Plus, you only need feed an alarm with a tiny amount of electricity to keep it running, whereas a dog requires a bed, a blanket, food, water and, later on, vets bills that will make your eyes water.THIS week, a car crashed through my fence, turning it and an expensive new gate into matchsticks.By the time I got there, the car was gone. But there was still a lot of “police aware” tape fluttering about in the breeze.So I called the nearest station, which was approximately  miles away, as I needed to contact the driver to talk about insurance. Sadly, however, while the police are “aware” of the incident, they are not prepared to give me any details.Mustn’t grumble, though. While it will cost a few hundred quid to get everything mended, I must accept that the police have much more important things to do, such as investigating dead people who weren’t paedophiles.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc no longer loved broadcaster
story: If you are a lavishly overpaid BBC presenter or senior manager with your snout stuffed deep into the corporation’s publicly-funded trough, then three quid is nothing — around the price of a semi-skimmed latte made with almond milk from that delightful little café outside Broadcasting House.But coming when it did — immediately after the BBC’s wretchedly biased coverage of the moment we left the European Union — hiking the archaic telly tax felt grotesquely provocative.And I realised that the BBC’s big problem today is that it is unloved. The young folk born this century, like my -year-old daughter, do not watch it. The BBC means nothing to Generation YouTube.And the millions of us who grew up with the Beeb no longer recognise it as the benign Auntie that gave us Doctor Who, Top Of The Pops, Le On Earth, Fawlty Towers, The Likely Lads and David Dimbleby staying up all night at the General Election.That old beloved BBC — endlessly entertaining, scrupulously fair — is dead now. The BBC’s coverage of the night we left the European Union was nothing less than shameful.Here was a moment of truly historical signicance, the kind of national event that the BBC was born to cover. And it was dished up like a dull night at the Eurovision Song Contest.Down in Parliament Square, awash with Union Jacks and peaceful, happy patriots, BBC reporter Geeta Guru-Murthy blurted: “It’s a very white crowd mostly” — to the bewilderment of the many black and Asian people who were there to celebrate.But, of course, the BBC continues to peddle the filthy little lie that Brexit has its roots in the racism of the bigoted British people.Meanwhile, Sophie Raworth sat primly in a BBC studio made up to look like the EU flag. The studio never turned red, white and blue. There was no sense that the largest vote for anything in British history was being honoured. Why must we pay £billion a year for this one-sided garbage My colleague Ally Ross has pointed out that BBC “comedy” shows like Have I Got News For You, Frankie Boyle’s New World Order and The Mash Report have all been larded with anti-Brexit orthodoxy for years. Now the predictably loony Remainer-speak even seeps into the poison the BBC drips into our children.On the day we left the EU, the BBC released a CBBC Horrible Histories special mocking British stupidity.Queen Victoria was accused of callously sweetening her tea with sugar harvested by slaves — even though slavery was abolished four years before Victoria came to the throne.Historian Andrew Roberts described the mocking film as “a stream of bigoted hatred directed at this country”. They truly don’t get it in Broadcasting House. Millions of licence fee payers are deeply offended by the BBC’s relentlessly anti-British, anti-Brexit sentiment.It is why we fell out of love with the BBC. There is talk about decriminalising non-payment of the licence fee, or making payment optional. But the BBC no longer represents the entire nation. It peddles the prejudices of the disappointed elite who run it.The BBC does not speak for the British people. It doesn’t even seem to like us very much. So why should we pay anything at all for this crap AFTER being overlooked at the Oscars for her sensational performance in Hustlers, the half-time show at the Super Bowl felt like the revenge of Jenner Lopez.But Hustlers is my favourite film of the past  months. Lopez deserved an Oscar for her role.And whoever wins Best Actress at the Oscars tonight, I bet they can’t slide down a pole like her.MICHELLE OBAMA always said: “When they go low, we go high.”Meaning that when the Republican opponents of President Obama struck a low blow the Obamas had a strict policy of keeping their cool, their dignity and the moral high ground.The most senior Democratic politician in America just failed to take Michelle Obama’s advice. At his State of the Union address, President Trump petulantly refused to shake the hand of NancyPelosi, the Democratic Speaker of the House of Representatives. Pelosi should have shrugged off Trump’s rudeness and perhaps laughed in Donald’s orange face.Instead, clearly boiling with rage, Nancy ripped a copy of Trump’s speech to pieces. As the speech was full of optimistic stuff about making America a fairer, more prosperous place, the only person Pelosi humiliated was herself.The Democrats are starting to make Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour Party look like an effective opposition.THE classic James Bond films – Dr No, From Russia With Love, Goldfinger – were all less than two hours long.But in the modern fashion for over-long movies – The Irishman clocks in at three hours and  minutes – the next Bond film, No Time To Die, will be the longest ever at almost three hours.Let’s hope that means plenty of Ana de Armas, , as Bond girl Paloma. And not too much of Daniel Craig, , moaning about ’s dodgy knees.Teenage girls are messier than teenage boys. But teenage boys are, in my experience, more likely to leave takeaway pizza under the bed for six months for the mice to nibble.And when vermin move in, you really long for your little darling to move out.SUCKING up to the millionaire snowflakes in the audience, Prince William complained about the lack of ersity at the Baftas.I don’t believe it. This year a black actor, Micheal Ward, won the Rising Star Bafta for gang film Blue Story. Six years ago,  Years A Slave won Best Picture, competing with epic Hollywood fare like Gravity.If the film or performance is good enough, then the Baftas is colour blind.The real lack of ersity is among British actors. These days most of them went to Eton with Prince William. Now that’s what I call a lack of ersity.A SURVEY reveals that  per cent of Canadians are against paying the £million to-£million-a-year security bill for Harry and Meghan’s new le.Wherever they lay their hats, from Toronto to Tinsel Town, there is only one sucker who will ever pay for Harry and Meghan’s security. The poor old British taxpayer.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: queen calls meghan markle prince harry back
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex moved to Canada after announcing they were quitting as royals and becoming financially independent.But the -year-old monarch has reportedly asked them toto the UK next month for the service at Westminster Abbey.If the couple attend the March  event, it will be the first royal engagement for Meghan, , since they quit.And the Sunday Times reported the couple will make a round of final official engagements in March before ing back to North America.The couple attended the Commonwealth Service last year, with Meghan heavily pregnant with Archie.Theto the UK comes after Harry and Meghan released their bombshell statement that they were leaving the Royal Family - story: The family had gone out for a walk amid the Storm Ciara carnage, despite severe weather warnings from the Met Office yesterday.As the strong gales whipped through the country the youngster was filmed being shoved off the pavement by a gust of wind.The youngster and their family appeared to be running as they tried to escape the wet and windy weather.And as one of the parents lost control of a buggy they were forced to run after their little one as the child tumbled into the road.Chasing after a sibling the youngster skidded on a puddle and fell to the floor before being buffeted into the street.Onlookers screamed as the youngster slipped and fell as a parent rushed to help - also fighting the wind.He had been out in Blackpool, Lancs yesterday at .pm with one other child.Another woman pushing a buggy was walking alongside them.One witness said: “It was a really daft thing to do. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK has confirmed four more cases of coronavirus - taking the total number of known infected patients to eight. China has recorded  deaths and currently has over , cases of the deadly virus. This morning, the government declared a serious and imminent threat to public health after a patient quarantined in Arrowe Park Hospital in Merseyside attempted to abscond. Health Secretary Matt Hancock revealed the new measures this morning in an announcement that gives the government additional powers to fight the spread of the virus. The increased risk level allows the government to legally forcibly hold a person in quarantine. This morningaposs announcement comes after  more people onboard the quarantined Diamond Princess cruise ship have tested positive. Meanwhile, authorities are trying to trace everyone who may have come into contact with a so-called apossuper-speaderapos of coronavirus. The man, who attended a business conference in Singapore, then went to a French ski resort before flying back to Britain on an easyJet plane. He then attended the Grenadier Pub in Hove, Sussex. among other places, before developing symptoms and going to hospital to be tested. What are the symptoms of coronavirus  While a person with the virus can show no outward symptoms, early signs can include a fever, diarrhea, a dry cough, shortness of breath and general body aches. Some patients also report feeling tired and confused. More serious cases of the virus can lead to a high fever, kidney failure and pneumonia. While the disease is being treated as an imminent threat in the UK, some of the symptoms of coronavirus are similar to those seem in other respiratory conditions - such as the flu or the common cold. What is the NHS advice  If you have recently travelled to a high-risk area - oryouaposve been in contact with somebody who has - and you develop symptoms, you should contact NHS  for advice. You should not go to the doctor or to hospital, asyou have the virus, you may risk spreading it to others. The NHS is asking anybody who has recently travelled to Wuhan to self-quarantine themselves for  days and call  to report your recent stay.  If you get a cough, high temperature or feel short of breath within  days of ing from other parts of China, including Macao and Hong Kong, Thailand, Japan, Republic of Korea, Taiwan, Singapore or Malaysia - you should stay indoors and avoid contact with other people and also call NHS  to tell them of your recent travel. Avoid using public transportyou appear to have symptoms. To avoid catching or spreading the virus, the NHS advise washing hands after coughing or sneezing and throw away tissues used. Using alcohol gel or washing hands after using public transport and avoiding touching eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands  Who is most at risk from coronavirus  People of all ages can contract coronavirus, but once caught itaposs more dangerous for young children, the elderly, people with pre-existing health conditions, or people with weakened immune systems.  Why has the UK declared an aposimminent threatapos  The UK Health Secretary has declared that the incidence or transmission of the Coronavirus is a serious and imminent threat to public health. Tory Matt Hancockaposs announcement gives him emergency powers to stop people leaving quarantine. A statement from the Department for Health said: In accordance with Regulation , the Secretary of State declares that the incidence or transmission of novel coronavirus constitutes a serious and imminent threat to public health. The measures outlined in these regulations are considered as an effective means of delaying or preventing further transmission of the virus. Itaposs understood he took the decision because someone threatened to abscond from a quarantine centre at Arrowe Park Hospital, Merseyside. Scores of Brits are in isolation there after  arrived from Wuhan for two weeksapos quarantine on January . The new law will give officials power to stop someone leaving. A source told the Mirror: Someone was threatening to abscond over the weekend. The source said the move was as much for the personaposs own safety as the safety of the public. They added: Overwhelmingly everyone who has been in quarantine has been really good about it. Many of them refused to get on the plane unless they would be quarantined afterwards.  What does aposimminent threatapos mean  The phrasing of the governmentaposs statement is really important. It doesnapost say the Coronavirus itself is an imminent threat - it says the transmission of it is. So the imminent threat is actually the specic person who threatened to leave, not the virus as a whole. Ministers needed to use this language to justy making emergency laws that havenapost yet been seen by Parliament. Is the threat to the public changed  No. Government officials say the threat to the public was still moderate this morning, despite the new declaration.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA row has erupted between Boris Johnsonaposs partner Carrie Symonds and his chief advisor Dominic Cummings over the Cabinet reshuffle, it has been claimed. Miss Symonds is apparently backing ministers who claim Mr Cummingsapos heavy-handed treatment of ministers, officials and journalists is harming the Prime Ministeraposs image, according to Treasury sources. Reports that the advisor urged the PM to sack Chancellor Sajid Javid and Defence Secretary Ben Wallace - two ministers with close links to Miss Symonds - has stoked the flames of the feud. Mr Johnson is said to be against firing Mr Javid but how secure Mr Wallace remains is unclear with a reshuffle likely to happen this week, reports the Daily Mail. Mr Cummings is also understood to be looking to remove several Tory ministerial special advisers, some who are close to Miss Symonds. The Prime Minister could be dragged into the centre of a potentially damaging power struggle between the pair - the most powerful members of his Cabinet of key advisors. Miss Symonds and Mr Cummings each have prominent Cabinet allies and hobby horses fighting their corners. The former joined the party as a press officer a decade ago before being pushed up to director of communications three years ago, working for senior Conservatives John Whittingdale, Zac Goldsmith and Mr Javid.  She is described as a skilled networker, as well as being a environmental campaigner, with her animal welfare views and stance on the release of violent criminals having influenced Mr Johnson. But she left the Tories in August . She was allegedly accused of claiming thousands of pounds of unauthorised expenses. Mr Cummings, meanwhile, pioneered radical school reforms as special adviser to then-Education Secretary Michael Gove and is hailed as the genius behind the Vote Leave campaign in aposs EU referendum. During a party on January , marking Brexit night, the Prime Minister praised his chief advisor for coming up with the powerful aposGet Brexit Doneapos slogan, paving the way for his landslide General Election victory in December.  Mr Cummingsapos war on the mainstream media since then though has seen him come under fire, including recently banning reporters from organisations considered hostile to the Government, resulting in a revolt of Westminster lobby journalists. He had also banned ministersapos special advisors lunching with journalists, to avoid stories being leaked, though both he and Miss Symonds have close ties with certain senior journalists. It is also understood he is behind a Number  campaign to chop the BBC down to size, including blocking ministers from appearing on Radio aposs Today show, claiming it is anti-Tory. A Treasury source told the Mail: There was always a risk that Carrie and Dom were going to fall out and that the PM would get caught in the crossfire.

story: NewsBrit couple refused PIP benefit for dementia after moving back from AustraliaLynne and Alan Crooks, from Middlesbrough, moved back to the north east after living in Australia for eight years - before Alan was diagnosed with dementia and Lynne had to become his full-time carerShareCommentsByMike Brown:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsAlan and Lynne Crooks ed to the UK two years ago after living in Australia " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA British couple say they were refused Personal Independence Payment benefits following a devastating dementia diagnosis - because they had previously lived in Australia. Lynne and Alan Crooks, from Middlesbrough, moved back to the north east two years ago after living in Australia for eight years. However within weeks Alan was showing signs of dementia, and when he was finally diagnosed more than a year later in April , Lynne became his full-time carer. But she was shocked to discover Alan did not qualy for the PIP benefit and because of that she was unable to claim Carersapos Allowance. The blow left them struggling to make ends meet, and now they are warning others thinking of ing to the UK after Brexit to check their entitlements. The Department for Work and Pensions , responsible for making decisions on claims, said it has always published its eligibility criteria for benefits on its website. Both Alan and Lynne, who lived in Middlesbrough all their lives until emigrating in , paid National Insurance contributions for more than  years and had been reassured they would qualy for state pensions. However the couple, who now live in Seaham, were unaware of rules that meant they had to be resident in the UK for two years before making a claim for PIP and Carers Allowance, reports Chronicle Live. Lynne said: “We had no idea about Alan’s illness when we made the decision toto the UK. Not being able to claim these benefits for the past two years feels like we have been penalised for emigrating in the first place. “It has been really tough and we have had to rely on family to get through this, especially as I can’t work anymore because Alan needs me  .” Former painter and decorator Alan, , has Semantic Dementia, a rare form of the condition that affects language skills. Lynne, , continued: “Alan is unable to identy everyday objects and their uses. He can no longer speak, read or write with the exception of copying his first name and saying ‘yes’. Everything he has ever been taught has been erased from his memory. The way it was described to me by his doctor was to think of the brain as a dictionary. Most people can access pages and pages of words, but Alan’s pages are blank. The couple, who have two children, ed to the UK with the intention of ‘doing something exciting every day’ after le Down Under didnapost work out as they’d hoped. But their plans to travel and socialise ground to a halt when Alan became ill. Since then, Lynne says support from Alzheimer’s Society has been invaluable.  Rowena Carr, a Dementia Support Worker for the charity, has been advising the couple on how to ensure they don’t miss out on the benefits they are entitled to once they qualy in March, as well as other support they can access. The stress they have been under over the past two years could have torn many couples apart, but Lynne says it has only made them stronger. She added: “Alan and I were childhood sweethearts. When I was five and he was six we’d sit on top of his mam’s shed and look at the stars. We started courting when I was  and this coming November we will celebrate our th wedding anniversary. So, Alan has always been part of my le. At the end of the day, I love him and dementia won’t change that. I knowthe roles were reversed, heaposd do the same for me. Official advice on the DWP website says that to claim PIP, you must be aged  or over and have not reached state pension age.
